Award.AwardTitle: EAGER - Values in Design for Future Internet Architecture - Next Phase

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
An EAGER grant for the Values In Design analysis for Future Internet Architectures--Next Phase (VID4FIA-NP) project supports experimentation with a new model for interdisciplinary collaboration, using the Future Internet Architecture projects as an exciting testbed, and integrating social, ethical, legal, and economic issues with the technical work of the FIA-NP project teams. VID4FIA-NP will build a network of VID experts and find common ground with the challenges faced by the FIA projects, using the VID methodologies for analyzing and designing technology that recommends social values that can serve as design requirements alongside more traditional technical constraints. These activities will produce events that connect VID approaches with the prototyping and testing process, and working papers, possible joint publications and other documents formalizing our findings and methods.

Intellectual Merit: Within the extensive community of researchers and scholars there are diverse, hotly contested views on what it means to say that technology is or is not value free. There are smaller demonstrations of the claim that features of technology can actively be adjusted to yield morally and socially relevant outcomes. VID4FIA-NP will make significant, convincing contributions to this debate by providing opportunities for social scientists, humanists, economists, legal and policy experts, and technical experts to collaborate on gritty design features that are socially and ethically important. Beyond potential contributions to the general understanding of social dimensions of technology, the project could yield insights into how to operationalize abstract concepts such as security, privacy, etc. and how to implement them in architecture, protocol, mechanism, etc. Not only could these contributions directly affect the FIA-NP projects, they could have significance for IT design generally, and even beyond, to other technologies.

Broader Impacts: Living with the consequences of technology, it is inevitable that we applaud some and bemoan others. Such evaluation can be retrospective, but for approaches in the VID network, there is commitment to pro-action, making adjustments in material elements of systems and devices systematically can affect socially relevant outcomes. Aware of the pitfalls of naive technological determinism, the payout measured in terms of systems and artifacts that promote--or do not subvert--attainment of societal values, is potentially great. The opportunity to test out these ideas in a research context as ambitious as the FIA-NP projects holds promise for better technology and deeper understanding of the mutual shaping influence of material design on the one hand and values on the other.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Values-in-Design (VID) Council is an interdisciplinary group of experts from a variety of academic disciplines including law and legal studies, science and technology studies (STS), computer science, philosophy, and information science. As members of the VID Council, these scholars have worked with recipients of the second phase of the National Science Foundation's Future Internet Architecture Initiative (FIA) large projects grants to identify,

This “next phase” of the VID Council extends the work of the first Values In Design Council, constituted, initially, to work with the first phase of the Future Internet Architecture projects that began in 2010. Over the past two years, VID Council members have served as analysts and consultants to the FIA projects, both at general project meetings and as embedded experts with particular technical teams

Intellectual Merit

Council members have played a variety of roles over the course of the FIA project in developing tomorrow’s novel network architecture and broadening the conversation around the design of technical systems with values in mind. These activities are all components of Values-in-Design (VID), an approach to analyzing and designing technology bearing in mind societal values (ethical and political) as a feature of design, not left for discovery post fact. These activities have included:

a)     working with technical experts to identify both broad themes and specific technical junctures in the network architecture design process in which values-critical technical decisions arise;

b)    calling attention to a variety of design parameters and variations that highlight different sets of relevant values, and the ways of which different technical decisions might shape values outcomes;

c)     developing rich conceptual understandings of relevant values alongside technical team members, and scaffolding these findings into technical suggestions; and

d)    for and with project investigators, directly operationalizing values to enable transition into design features within the novel network architectures.

Broader Impacts

The second iteration of the Council has taken active role in workshopping scenarios alongside the technical experts, and exploring particular VID questions in conjunction with the project teams and culminating in a PI meeting hosted by VID Council members in November of 2015. Working with FIA PI investigators, the Council members have explored the interplay of values embodied in design with respective values embodied in law and policy; and where possible, verifying values in design through prototyping, user testing and other empirical analyses.

During its second phase, members of the VID Council expanded research connections and interactions with the FIA technical teams as the Next Phase focused increasingly on implementation and application scenarios. It continued to alert of all FIA researchers to the centrality of values considerations and has developed a summary guide to best practices for future collaborations in a similar vein. This phase of the Council has been committed to expanding one-on-one research collaborations and publication opportunities with members of FIA technical teams. Building on successful partnerships formed during the first phase of the FIA, several new partnerships and projects were formed between Council members and particular technical teams, and the Council has continued its collaboration and interdisciplinary analysis of FIA projects at PI meetings. The VID Council has also served as a model for other similar groups connected to NSF-funded projects (e.g. the Big Data Council) exploring the intersections and impacts of digital technologies and social forces.
